citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee has not been following their written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) approved by their attending
veterinarian. The PVC states to avoid the use of Marquis in puppies under 6 weeks of age. Records showed that a puppy
with a date of birth of January 6th, 2023 was given Marquis on January 27, 2023 and February 10, 2023. Giving a
medication to animals that are too young could cause harmful effects to their health. Each dealer and exhibitor shall
assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care and to
oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use. Correct by ensuring that medications are given at the
prescribed age in accordance with the PVC and that the guidelines in the PVC are followed. Correct by April 21, 2023.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An expired drug and supplements were found in the facility. A bottle of Amoxicillin was found with an expiration date of
March 23, 2023. Additionally, a tube of Forti Cal had an expiration date of February 2023 and a box of FortiFlora had an
expiration date of November 2021. The use of expired drugs and supplements may have reduced effectiveness or cause
harmful effects to the animals. Each dealer shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include
the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The facility must ensure
medications and supplements are not expired. Correct by April 21, 2023.

The licensee does not have an adequate written contingency plan. An inadequate contingency plan can result in lack of
readiness and a delay in response to care for animals during emergencies or disasters. Dealers must develop, document,
and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their
animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be
detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their possession). A contingency plan includes emergency
situations the licensee may experience, outlines specific tasks required to be carried out during emergencies such as
detailed animal evacuation instructions or shelter-in-place instructions and provisions for providing backup sources of food
and water as well as sanitation, ventilation, bedding, veterinary care, identify who will be responsible for fulfilling these
tasks, and address how response and recovery will be handled in terms of materials, resources, and training needed.
Ensure that an adequate written contingency plan is developed and followed in case of an emergency. Correct by May 18,
2023.

Excessive chew damage is present on the surfaces of the enclosures. Chew damage was seen on the front of most of the
enclosures and also on numerous dividers between the enclosures. Chew damage on walls and dividers cannot be
properly sanitized and can creates sharp points that can cause injury to the animals. All surfaces must be maintained on a
regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities-including houses, dens, and other furniture type fixtures and objects within the
facility- that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled. Correct by ensuring that all
surfaces are maintained or replaced when worn or soiled. Correct by May 18, 2023.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Enclosures are not being sanitized properly. The walls of 12 enclosures and several doors between the indoor/outdoor
areas are soiled with a buildup of brown material. The licensee states he sprays down with a disinfectant daily, but that
the brown material was last cleaned off in December of last year. Appropriate sanitization must include a thorough
cleaning of the surfaces to remove organic material and mineral buildup. This process must be performed at least once
every 2 weeks or as often as necessary to prevent accumulation of the brown material.
Water receptacles are not being sanitized at an appropriate frequency. The licensee states that the water receptacles are
sanitized once a month.
Inadequate and infrequent sanitization allows the growth of disease-causing agents that may increase the risk of health
hazards towards the animals. Used primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for dogs must be properly
sanitized at least once every 2 weeks and more often if necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste,
excreta, and other disease hazards. Correct by appropriately cleaning and sanitizing primary enclosures and all food and
water receptacles, including removal of all organic material and mineral buildup before applying detergent and/or
disinfectant solutions, at least once every 2 weeks or more often if necessary. Correct by April 27, 2023.

The licensee was unable to provide the documentation of fecal screening tests for puppies. The licensee stated that fecal
tests are performed on all the puppies, but there were no medical records documenting the puppies’ identities, the dates
which the tests were performed, or findings and results. Failure to document screening tests and the results of the testing
may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the dogs are receiving adequate veterinary care. Medical
records must be maintained and include the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or other required or
recommended test or examination. Correct by documenting the results of all testing and ensure that medical records are
complete and contain the required information. Correct by April 27, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
KATHRYN CAMPITELLI, KENNEL & SMALL PET FIELD SPECIALIST n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee has not been following their written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) approved by their attending 
veterinarian. The PVC states to avoid the use of Marquis in puppies under 6 weeks of age. Records showed that a puppy

oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use. Correct by ensuring that medications are given at the 
prescribed age in accordance with the PVC and that the guidelines in the PVC are followed. Correct by April 21, 2023. 
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An expired drug and supplements were found in the facility. A bottle of Amoxicillin was found with an expiration date of 
March 23, 2023. Additionally, a tube of Forti Cal had an expiration date of February 2023 and a box of FortiFlora had an

harmful effects to the animals. Each dealer shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include

the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. The facility must ensure 
medications and supplements are not expired. Correct by April 21, 2023. 
2.134(a) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The licensee does not have an adequate written contingency plan. An inadequate contingency plan can result in lack of 
readiness and a delay in response to care for animals during emergencies or disasters. Dealers must develop, document, 
and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their 
animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be 
detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their possession). A contingency plan includes emergency 
situations the licensee may experience, outlines specific tasks required to be carried out during emergencies such as 
detailed animal evacuation instructions or shelter-in-place instructions and provisions for providing backup sources of food 
and water as well as sanitation, ventilation, bedding, veterinary care, identify who will be responsible for fulfilling these 
tasks, and address how response and recovery will be handled in terms of materials, resources, and training needed. 
Ensure that an adequate written contingency plan is developed and followed in case of an emergency. Correct by May 18, 
2023. 
3.1(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Excessive chew damage is present on the surfaces of the enclosures. Chew damage was seen on the front of most of the 
enclosures and also on numerous dividers between the enclosures. Chew damage on walls and dividers cannot be 
properly sanitized and can creates sharp points that can cause injury to the animals. All surfaces must be maintained on a 
regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities-including houses, dens, and other furniture type fixtures and objects within the

facility- that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled. Correct by ensuring that all

3.11(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
Enclosures are not being sanitized properly. The walls of 12 enclosures and several doors between the indoor/outdoor 
areas are soiled with a buildup of brown material. The licensee states he sprays down with a disinfectant daily, but that 
the brown material was last cleaned off in December of last year. Appropriate sanitization must include a thorough 
cleaning of the surfaces to remove organic material and mineral buildup. This process must be performed at least once 
every 2 weeks or as often as necessary to prevent accumulation of the brown material. 
 
Water receptacles are not being sanitized at an appropriate frequency. The licensee states that the water receptacles are 
sanitized once a month. 
 
Inadequate and infrequent sanitization allows the growth of disease-causing agents that may increase the risk of health 
hazards towards the animals. Used primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for dogs must be properly 
sanitized at least once every 2 weeks and more often if necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, 
excreta, and other disease hazards. Correct by appropriately cleaning and sanitizing primary enclosures and all food and 
water receptacles, including removal of all organic material and mineral buildup before applying detergent and/or

3.13(b)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

The licensee was unable to provide the documentation of fecal screening tests for puppies. The licensee stated that fecal 
tests are performed on all the puppies, but there were no medical records documenting the puppies’ identities, the dates 
which the tests were performed, or findings and results. Failure to document screening tests and the results of the testing 
may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the dogs are receiving adequate veterinary care. Medical 
records must be maintained and include the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or other required or 
recommended test or examination. Correct by documenting the results of all testing and ensure that medical records are 
complete and contain the required information. Correct by April 27, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KATHRYN CAMPITELLI, KENNEL & SMALL PET FIELD SPECIALIST n
